name: N-[(Z)-2-bromo-2-phenylethenyl]-N-hydroxyaniline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2869

name: N-[(Z)-2-bromo-2-phenylethenyl]-N-hydroxyaniline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2869
Reason:
The basic unit for this compound can be considered as styrene, which has a melting point of approximately -30°C. Adding functional groups and structural changes will shift this melting point:
- Phenyl group: +40°C (aromatic ring increases intermolecular forces)
- N-hydroxyaniline group: +70°C (hydrogen bonding due to the -OH group and nitrogen's lone pair)
- Bromine atom: +50°C (adds significant molecular weight and size, which increases London dispersion forces)
- (Z)-configuration double bond: -10°C (compared to an (E)-configuration, which has more steric hindrance, a (Z)-configuration can lead to slightly weaker intermolecular interactions because of its less extended structure)
The increases due to aromaticity, hydrogen bonding, and the bromine atom are somewhat mitigated by the (Z)-configuration of the double bond.

name: N-[(Z)-2-bromo-2-phenylethenyl]-N-hydroxyaniline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2869
Reason:
The basic unit for this compound can be considered as styrene, which has a melting point of approximately -30°C. Adjusting this value based on the added functional groups and structural changes gives a predicted melting point as follows: 
- Phenyl group: +40°C x 2 (there are two phenyl groups, which increases the intermolecular forces due to their aromatic nature)
- N-hydroxyaniline group: +70°C (introduction of hydrogen bonding due the -OH group and nitrogen's lone pair contributes significantly to the melting point)
- Bromine atom: +50°C (the large bromine atom adds significant molecular weight and size, increasing Van der Waals forces)
- (Z)-configuration double bond: -10°C (Z-configuration might lead to slightly weaker intermolecular interactions compared to E-configuration)
The combined effect of these modifications leads to an increase in melting point relative to the basic styrene unit, but because the Actual value is given as 180°C, the increases from phenyl groups and bromine have been underestimated in this prediction.
